title-group.article-title: Comment: Empathy and Self-Recognition in Phylogenetic and Ontogenetic Perspective: Commentary on Bischof-Köhler

contrib-group.aff: Cluster of Excellence “Languages of Emotion,” Freie Universität Berlin, Germany

author-notes.corresp: Gisela Klann-Delius, Cluster of Excellence “Languages of Emotion,” Freie Universität Berlin, Habelschwerdter Allee 45, D-14195 Berlin, Germany. Email: gisela.klann-delius@fu-berlin.de

abstract.p: The very impressive findings on empathy in relation to self-recognition are interpreted in a theoretical framework within which the central concept of synchronous identification, the consequence of compassion, and the relation between maturation and socialization appear to be debatable.

body.p: Among the numerous conceptions of empathy (Batson, 2009), Bischof-Köhler’s phylogenetic and ontogenetic perspective on the development of empathy stands out with her proposal “that empathy is the first mechanism in phylogeny and ontogeny that conveys insight into the subjective experience of another and that it can be explained without the abilities necessary for a theory of mind” (Bischof-Köhler, 2012, p. 41). According to Bischof-Köhler as well as other scholars (e.g., Decety, 2011; Singer & Lamm, 2009), empathy entails an affective and a cognitive component, whereas emotional contagion lacks a cognitive and perspective taking lacks an affective component. The cognitive component of empathy sets in with the child’s ability for (not yet conscious) mental imagination, as reflected in self-recognition, which gives raise to self–other distinction; this enables the empathizer to recognize the other as the source of the emotion; that empathic behavior that goes together with self-recognition is beautifully demonstrated by the data Bischof-Köhler presents in her article. The ability to emotionally empathize with another person is based on a second cognitive requirement, the synchronic identification, which ensures that “Me and You appear essentially identical.… The subjective I … relates to You similarly to the way it relates to Me” (Bischof-Köhler, 2012, p. 44).

This conception of empathy is a highly inspiring proposal, most notably because it seriously takes into account the fact that nonhuman and human primates share an evolutionary heritage, showing up no less in the realm of empathy (de Waal, 2008) as in the realm of emotions in general (Panksepp, 1998). Nevertheless, this conception of empathy relies on assumptions not every scholar might be willing to share.

One problematic assumption concerns the notion of synchronic identification, which is meant to explain the emotional component of empathy in addition to the cognitive one, being based on the self–other distinction. The concept of synchronic identification assumes that the empathic sharing of feelings is induced by the perception that the YOU is of the same kind as the ME. Apart from the problem that the notion “identification” is not sufficiently clear, one wonders precisely how the emotion transfer from YOU to ME/I is thought to work. In order to share the affective state of another person, for example, the other’s distress when accidentally breaking his/her spoon while eating a desert (one of the examples Bischof-Köhler gives in her article), the child probably has to inhibit his/her own affective state (Decety & Meyer, 2008). In addition, affectively empathizing with the feelings of the other probably involves the activation of bodily feelings the child has experienced when being in a comparable feeling state; this perspective of linking perceptions, concepts, and feeling has been proposed by Damasio (2000) and Barrett and Bar (2009).

The second point relates to the consequences of the empathic feeling: What enables the empathic child to take appropriate actions? One outcome of the affective sharing and of the cognitive components of empathy is compassion, motivating prosocial intervention and helping behavior. This motivating force is modulated by factors such as familiarity, autonomy, competency, and quality of relation to the other. The data Bischof-Köhler presents clearly show that empathizers engage significantly more often in helping behavior, but it is not sufficiently clear how motivation is aligned to subsequent helping behavior. In order to come up with the appropriate actions the child possibly draws on his own experiences in comparable situations, thus activating stored links of feelings and corresponding actions. In order to specify the route from the feeling of compassion to action one has to explicate how feelings, thoughts, and actions are intertwined. There are some suggestions how to specify these relations (e.g., Barrett & Bar, 2009; Wilson-Mendenhall, Barrett, Simmons, & Barsalou, 2011), but these proposals await further empirical testing, especially with children.

The last remark concerns the rather strict division between maturational growth of empathy and its modulation by socialization (Bischoff-Köhler, 2012). It is certainly not debatable that all typically developing children show self-recognition and empathy in a specific age range. But this in itself does not prove a major role of maturation as opposed to socialization. Recent research in the field of epigenetics (e.g., Cromwell, 2011; Meaney & Szyf, 2005) has given support to the general claim that nature and nurture are seamlessly interwoven and that one major goal of today’s developmental research is to analytically and empirically disentangle the nature and the nurture part of human capacities such as empathy.
